messages.messageBody:
Shinsei,
I have been calling you sensei out of respect. Since I am the one
asking the questions and you are the one answering, you are my sensei.
I appreciate your help in everything. Have a great year and I hope to
talk with you some more sometime.
L.G.B.

Shinsei

messages.messageBody:
Sensei,
Happy New Year to you also!
You have been most helpful and I just want to thank
you. I really enjoyed seeing your picture on the
profile page! Wow!
I have a link of a picture of some kanji and
would like to know if this is the correct spelling for
Koumitsushi. I would be grateful for your help.
Thank You, L. Berry
If you want to write me off the list, my addres is:
wahmeister@...

http://home.i-plus.net/thorpe/kanji.jpg

messages.subject: Royal armouries UK
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all I was at the royal armouries Leeds UK yesterday. as always i took loads of photos. The sword cabinet has changed since my last visit and now contains
messages.messageBody:
Hi all

I was at the royal armouries Leeds UK yesterday. as
always i took loads of photos.

The sword cabinet has changed since my last visit and
now contains part of a provate collection. This
included 2 swords by Gassan Sadakazu and Gassan
Sadakatsu. The Sadakatsu was made to commemorate the
birth of emperor Akihito.

My favourite was the Nagamaki Naoshi which was
converted to a katana. Made in around 1300, it had a
dotanuki style kissaki.

Many of you have privately had photos from me before,
but to save recieving and sending laods of emails I
have put them all into zipped files on my web site for
you to download.

http://www.hanako.co.uk/Armouries/Armouries.htm

Have fun with them

paul

messages.subject: Re: Who was Goro Nyudo Kiyomitsushi
messages.msgSnippet: Hello. I heard Goro Nyudo Masamune(Koumitsushi) had rarely carved his name in his swords.But in some of his,the name Koumitsushi were used. No wonder Kiyo
messages.messageBody:
Hello.
I heard Goro Nyudo Masamune(Koumitsushi) had rarely carved his name
in his swords.But in some of his,the name "Koumitsushi" were used.

No wonder"Kiyo" in Fujiwara Kiyomitsu may sound "Kou" to non-
Japanese ,but its Kanji is different from "Kou"'s in"Koumitsushi".

Regards

messages.messageBody:
Sinsei,
Thank You for your help.

I have noticed that Koumitsu and Kiyomitsu appear to be the same name.
If I am correct, was the "Kou" used to set Masamune apart from the
Many Kiyomitsu's that came later? Thank You, LB

messages.subject: Re: Who was Goro Nyudo Kiyomitsushi
messages.msgSnippet: Akemasite Omedetou Gozaimasu(Happy New Year!) Goro Nyudo Koumitsushi...He is the great swordsmith in Kamakura Era though I don t know much about him. Shinsei
messages.messageBody:
Akemasite Omedetou Gozaimasu(Happy New Year!)

Goro Nyudo Koumitsushi...He is the great swordsmith in Kamakura Era
though I don't know much about him.

Shinsei

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Question...
messages.msgSnippet: Yes. Firearms were an aid, not the deciding factor. The terrain was not conducive to a Takeda charge, the combination of the Rengo-gawa river, the mud, and the
messages.messageBody:
Yes.

Firearms were an aid, not the deciding factor. The
terrain was not conducive to a Takeda charge, the
combination of the Rengo-gawa river, the mud, and the
Oda positions in the foothills, combined with the
palisade, made for a great disruptor. The effect with
the firearms was definitely a huge factor, but
considering the Oda had the terrain advantage in
ADDITION to outnumbering the Takeda 2 to 1, I firmly
believe that they would have won. Would it have been
as lopsided? No, it would have been much closer. As it
was, the fighting was very fierce, and the Oda had
over 6,000 casualties as it was.

messages.subject: Who was Goro Nyudo Kiyomitsushi
messages.msgSnippet: I just joined the group and wondered if perhaps someone would know who this man was in Japanese history? His name is Goro Nyudo Kiyomitsushi or (Koumitsushi).
messages.messageBody:
I just joined the group and wondered if perhaps someone
would know who this man was in Japanese history? His name is
Goro Nyudo Kiyomitsushi or (Koumitsushi).
Thanks, LB
